    Mr Seng Han Thong (Ang Mo Kio)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, every businessman has been saying time is bad and everyone agrees that it will be worse. Every day when we read the newspapers and listen to the news, we learn that more and more companies are winding up and many workers are retrenched. It is getting from bad to worse. More and more people are losing their jobs. We also hear a lot of grumblings from the people. Some companies have simply closed down and the workers lamented, "Retrenched today, no more job for me tomorrow!"

    Businessmen are grumbling, "The banks are most merciless, they keep on pressing us for payments." In June this year, the Government announced the off-Budget measures where $2 billion were pumped in to bring forward the construction of infrastructure, and to help the businessmen tide over the difficult times. But they say that the Government is not doing enough. More rebates should be given.

Column: 806



    Sir, many Singaporeans who are yet to be retrenched are worried that they would be retrenched. They are worried that once their CPF contribution is reduced, they will have problems servicing their housing loans. With all these worries, their confidence is lost. So at this time when we are threatened by this regional financial crisis we should pull ourselves together and face the problem together. In the short term, we should minimise unemployment and in the long term we will have to improve our competitiveness. To attain these targets, whether you are the employer, employee or Government, you must first of all have confidence and the determination to face the problems squarely and work out long-term strategies to strengthen our economy.

    I shall elaborate on the roles of the employers, employees and the Government. First, let us talk about the employers. When this financial crisis came all of a sudden, many companies were caught off-guard. When business is bad, they try ways and means to cut cost and resort to downsizing their operations. In many circumstances, our employers still have a heart. They would discuss with the union representatives and arrange for the workers to undergo retraining so that they can cross over to the high-tech industries and command higher wages. We say that the bosses do have a heart. An accountant friend of mine who works in an advertising company said that this year the company's business was reduced by 70% and most of the time the staff had nothing to do. The management then discussed with the staff and they all agreed that in order to keep their jobs and stay employed, they accepted a wage cut, and they are allowed to take on part-time jobs outside. So they retain good employer-employee relationship, the company could continue to survive and they have employees who have developed a strong sense of belonging.

    Sir, the unions affiliated to NTUC are working hand in hand with companies affected by this downturn. The workers are either on shorter work week or temporarily laid off or attending the Skills Redevelopment Programme (SRP).

Column: 807



    At the moment, employees who are retrenched are not confined to ordinary workers in the manufacturing sector and the service industry. Many managers and company executives are given the golden handshake. Even CEOs and General Managers could be retrenched. There are, in fact, more and more cases of this nature. These managers and executives are neither here nor there. It is difficult for them to secure alternative jobs. Some of them have to maintain their parents and support their families, with housing loans and car loans to service, and lots of other financial commitments. They are prepared to work - any kind of work! So long as they can get a job, they are prepared to accept any salary. But the employers say these people are over-qualified, they are very demanding and will not stay long in the job. So they do not even get a chance to go into the interview room. A 51 year-old manager told me that he had attended ten interviews, and had written lots of letters. Every time he attended an interview, he could tell from the expression of the interviewers that he did not stand a chance. He lamented, "If I do not go, I will have no opportunity. But if I go, I do not stand a chance. It is all the same."

    In Singapore, the Government is the biggest employer. The Government should take a leading role. In some Government departments where there are a lot of backlogs to clear, let some of these retrenched executives and managers be employed to clear the work. They have the management experience and expertise to take on these jobs.

Employees face the reality

    It is said that all good things in life do not last forever. If you say this a few years ago, not many people would believe in it. There used to be long queues to buy the million-dollar apartments and long queues to buy club memberships. There were long queues everywhere because people believed that where there was a queue, there was opportunity to make profits and amass a lot of money. With

Column: 808

this trend developing, many people were using future money to buy things that they do not need, just to impress others. When the financial crisis hits Singapore, we all realise that good things in life really do not last forever. We have to tighten our belts. It is a blessing in disguise because it makes people more realistic and they begin to realise the importance of upgrading themselves.

    Not so long ago, I participated in a dialogue session on foreign talents and a young lady told me that the taxi driver who drove her to the dialogue session spoke very good English.

    She found out from him that he was working as a manager and was retrenched. Since he spoke such good English, why should he work as a taxi driver? We should find a better job for him. I said, "Well, there are many taxi drivers who speak very good English. It does not mean that if one speaks good English, one should not be driving a taxi." I actually admire the courage of this ex-manager who dared to take up this job of a taxi driver. He is being realistic. He grabs a job first and then looks for something better. Actually driving a taxi is not a bad thing. I know of many taxi drivers who drive taxis in the day time and at night time they enjoy themselves by singing in the Teochew opera troupe. In the day time they work hard but at night they go about enjoying themselves by doing things they enjoy doing.

    Nowadays, many retrenched workers are working as taxi drivers. Even those who are not retrenched as yet, are also working as taxi drivers, just in case they are retrenched later on. So it is good to have such a sense of crisis.

    However, Singaporeans should try to upgrade themselves at all times and get better trained to ensure their employability. In the past, we said, "A skill in hand brings you benefit the whole life long." But now with technologies advancing all the time, your skill may soon become obsolete when the technology you are familiar with is replaced by new technologies. In order to avoid unemployment, you will have to possess many skills in

Column: 809

hand so that you can be employed all the time. I urge all Singaporeans to have this habit of lifelong training and participate in the training courses provided by the NTUC and the various self-help bodies so as to ensure lifelong employability.

Foreign talents

    Let me talk about the policy of attracting foreign talents. In recent years, the Government has been attracting a lot of foreign talents to help in our economic development. Foreign talents can be divided into three categories. The first category of foreign talents are the specialists like the R&D researchers, the computer experts, the medical specialists, etc. which we do not have. The second category of foreign talents are the teachers and nurses, etc., the type of people we are short of. These professions were very shorthanded in the past and not many people like to be nurses, but recently there was a change in mind. This year, for the first time, Nanyang Polytechnic has full enrolment for the nursing course. I think it is not because people change their mindset about being a nurse but it is because of the changing circumstances. The third category of foreign talents are those who are recruited to undertake jobs which Singaporeans do not wish to do, such as bus drivers, construction workers, etc. I understand that among our bus drivers in Singapore, some 40% are foreign workers. We issue work permits for people to do these jobs which Singaporeans do not wish to do.

    When discussing the policy of attracting foreign talents to come to Singapore, everyone supports the idea of getting these foreign talents here to strengthen our economy and to enhance our competitiveness. But now with the economic slowdown when many people are losing their jobs, many people are complaining. They say, "Why are we allowing so many foreign talents to come here? Why are they called `talents'? Are we not talents ourselves? Why don't you employ us?" In order to improve our economy, to increase our competitiveness, yes, we have to employ foreign workers but we must also look after our Singaporeans.

Column: 810

The famous poet Li Bai of the Tang Dynasty said, "Everyone is born a talent. I have my own niche." I must emphasise here that everyone is a talent, even a taxi driver is a talent. So we must make good use of talents and try not to have the mismatch of talents.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I suggest that the Government's policy on the attraction of foreign talent be more transparent. We should let everybody know that in each industry what are the job opportunities available every year. How many Singaporeans can we absorb and how many foreign talents do we need to absorb? At the same time, employers who are applying for work permits or professional passes should consider employing locals, especially the retrenched middle management people and executives. Only when we run out of these local talents, then can work permits be issued to foreign workers. The Government should also give a projection as to what are the jobs available, what can be done by locals and what are the vacancies that we need foreign talents to fill.

    The Government has already had the Retrenchment Advisory Scheme and the Employment Assistance Scheme. I suggest that the Ministry of Manpower publish the statistics of how many people have applied for jobs and what are the job vacancies available. Give some illustrations to let our people know what is the success rate of our job matching efforts. I suggest we consider allowing the middle management executives to be registered too, because nowadays there are so many middle management people or company executives who are retrenched. At the moment, many employers do not wish to employ the older workers because they feel that these people are more demanding. In fact, many people have lowered their expectations. A friend of mine was suddenly retrenched. He told me that when he returned home with the news of his retrenchment, he asked members of his family, "So, what am I going to do now?" The wife replied, "No problem. Let us dismiss our foreign maid. We can save about $700 a month." Then the daughter said, "Well, I will give private tuition." The son said, " I am in national

Column: 811

service. During the weekends, I can do some part-time jobs." Now, he has taken a new job which requires him to do typing, filing and all sorts of odd chores, and he is earning only one quarter of what he used to earn. But he said, "Never mind. I will carry on. I will work hard and I shall survive." So it is only in times of difficulty that you realize how precious your family is to you. The family gives him the support he much needed. For the time being, he may not be able to meet the payments such as income tax, PUB charges, housing loans, etc. I think the Government should be more sympathetic - allow them to defer payment or even to pay by instalments.

    Now, let me talk about the cost of doing business. We all know that in recent years, our wage cost has already been adjusted. The Ministers and top civil servants have their salaries cut. Civil servants have their bonuses reduced. Many private companies are implementing the wage restraint policy. Since the 1990s the property prices have gone up by about 300%. There is a chain reaction. For example, in a coffeeshop which is tendered for millions of dollars, a chicken rice stall has to pay rental of $3,000 to $4,000 a month. So let us think about it. How many plates of chicken rice has the stall-keeper got to sell in order to just pay his rent? I hope that the Government will give these property owners more rebates and we must see to it that their tenants share these rebates. Many tenants are telling me that up to now, they have not enjoyed any of these rebates that the owners are getting.

    Nowadays we have a lot of open-bidding exercises, for land sale, for COEs, etc, and all these tender exercises are absolutely transparent. The policy is correct. But many people feel that property prices can only go up but cannot go down. So everyone will start bidding higher and higher. Now all of a sudden, we know that the property price can go down and there is nothing that they could do. In this aspect, I think the Government should review the policy. We should do away with the speculative element so that

Column: 812

we will not commit the same mistake again in future. When we are reviewing our policy, we should also consider the outcome of the review so that everybody would benefit.

    Recently, the Ministry of Communications reviewed the policy of diesel tax. The saving of the diesel tax rebate is as much as $109 million. The Land Transport Authority makes it clear that the taxi drivers should be entitled to a share of this benefit. Recently, the three major taxi operator associations in Singapore reached an agreement with the taxi companies, whereby each principal taxi hirer shall have $750 paid into his Medisave Account for the next five years. So in five years, every taxi driver would have accumulated $3,500 in their Medisave Account. In all, $60 million will go to these taxi drivers, which is as much as 55% of the savings from the diesel tax. In the past, whenever the taxi drivers talked about the diesel tax, they would become angry. They would scold and abuse. But now, they are happy. I feel that this diesel tax is no longer a burden to them and the taxi drivers no longer have to worry about their contributions to Medisave. This is a win-win situation.

    In this example we can see that the employer does have a heart and the workers have the incentives to work hard. This is a time for everyone to work together with one heart. As long as the Government has a realistic, pragmatic policy to reduce business cost, I am sure we would be able to overcome all odds and come out of this economic crisis stronger and wiser.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion exhorting the Government and the people to rally together so that Singapore will emerge from this regional crisis even more competitive and resilient.

    Having a strong, able and honest Government in Singapore is necessary under any circumstance. But it is not a sufficient condition for the survival of our nation, whether economically or socially. A resilient and equally strong population is just as important. During this crisis,

Column: 813

there is no doubt that the Government's role as a leader and facilitator of changes is crucial to Singapore's ability to not just survive the crisis, but also to emerge the stronger for it. To do so, Singaporeans should support the Government constructively and should not despair nor be overwhelmed by pessimism. Sir, the Government should rally the people in the following ways:

    Firstly, view challenges collectively. Reflecting on our own past, as we struggled through the last three decades, there can be no denial that both the Government and the people worked hand-in-hand as there was a sense of ownership of a common destiny and a common vision. There was mutual trust that everyone would strive towards the common good. This did not mean that there was no suffering, no pain nor adjustments. But it did mean that everyone was prepared to work towards a longer term goal even though there was going to be hardship in the interim.

    This was again evident as we rode out the downturn in the mid-80s. Painful decisions were taken. Singaporeans rallied behind this Government and we emerged better able to tap growth potential.

    The financial and economic crisis that we are now confronted with has no precedent. It has hit all Asian countries with such ferocity that it would be quite impossible to be spared. Even though we have a relatively sound financial system and competitive business infrastructure, we are still adversely affected.

    Estimates on how long this crisis will plague us have not been encouraging. This means that for us in Singapore, the pain, particularly from unemployment and extremely challenging business conditions, is likely to intensify over the next year. How we react to this monumental crisis will determine how we will fare in the medium, if not, longer term.

    The current crisis resembles a mighty earthquake, which unfortunately has many epi-centres within the Asian region, each capable of triggering equally damaging aftershocks. The role of the

Column: 814

Government is therefore to help prepare people to cope with the devastating effects and we have to recognise that there is very little, if at all, that it can do to prevent another aftershock from happening.

    So how do we cope with this crisis? Do we begin by shifting blame, say, to our employees or the Government? Understandably, this may be a reaction triggered by despair for those who have been retrenched, or badly affected by the plunge in property or stock market values, or financially crippled by higher interest rates. However, once we start drawing lines of division and forming separate camps, we will not be able to be on top of the situation.

    Reaction to the current call to stay employable may be a good illustration of how we can view these challenges, literally, as one people or as different parties. Do we see the need to be constantly trained and upgraded as a necessary survival skill for all Singaporeans or is it simply an end unto itself, the road to another job?

    If we see training as an obligation of employers or the Government, then the motivation to get trained will not be high nor sustainable. However, if we see this as a means to remaining employable, on account of our continual upgrading of skills, then we will fully realise the benefits of the various schemes put in place by employers, unions and the Government. As Mr Lim Swee Say has elaborated, a change of mindset is crucial at this stage, otherwise those who have been retrenched and who have gone onto training schemes, will emerge more disappointed, when they are still unable to find jobs. In the final analysis, our sustainable edge will be knowledge-driven, which implies that Singaporeans would always have to be ahead. This is only possible if we constantly upgrade ourselves for our own sake. The Government should help by constantly raising awareness amongst the workforce and companies of the changing skill-sets needed over time. More incentives for individuals to upgrade themselves should also be made available.

Column: 815



    Secondly, be prepared to make adjustments. We feel helpless or even frustrated when we have just been retrenched or have failed to find a similar-paying job for the last nine months. But, we should all ask ourselves the question - whose responsibility is it to secure jobs for us?

    Somewhat, ironically, the very same factor, that is, a tight labour market, which has led to strong income growth in the past decade, is also the cause of our mental unpreparedness in coping with unemployment during this crisis. To a large extent, this reflects our vulnerability as an economy with no natural resources and one which is so dependent on the human factor.

    Government agencies, such as the Economic Development Board, slog hard to garner foreign investments which will in turn create jobs for us. This has been accompanied by judicious manpower planning for the necessary skills. So far, the matching has worked well, which has made job placement a fairly straightforward, if not easy, task for employees. Therefore, the sense of competition for jobs and the need to make oneself presentable, skill-wise especially, is seldom felt. This is perhaps our greatest challenge - to understand the need to stay relevant and flexible at all times, so that in trying times such as these, we can make the necessary adjustments, both mentally and physically.

    Sir, this is therefore not an issue of what else the Government should be doing to reduce unemployment. Certainly, there is no question that the Government should drive retraining efforts, with the necessary funding and placement assistance, to help those who are seeking to stay employable. But the response of Singaporeans must be compatible in order for the whole exercise to be a constructive one. For example, as Mr Lim Swee Say has alluded to, Singaporeans have, justifiably, called on the Government to reduce reliance on foreign labour and divert jobs to locals instead, in a bid to lower unemployment. However, will there be enough Singaporeans to fill these jobs, for example, in

Column: 816

the construction industry? So the question really is: will Singaporeans be prepared to make adjustments to their expectations and take on jobs which may not always be ideal but which will nonetheless reduce unemployment and the related financial problems?

    Thirdly, do not allow pessimism to overwhelm us. Daily headlines just do not make for pleasant reading nowadays - they merely reinforce some of our greatest fears that the whole region is plunging into a recession. Acknowledging how badly even the Singapore economy has deteriorated is necessary and painful, but we should try to look beyond this crisis.

    We should not allow pessimism to drag us down the economic spiral. For we are a small economy and if we continue to wallow in self-pity, we will miss out on the opportunities to reposition ourselves. We should try to resist the temptation to pour our reserves into repairing depressed sectors per se, but to instead focus on how we can deploy them towards consolidating our position economically. This would have favourable long-term implications and will help ensure that we have sufficient growth impetus beyond this crisis.

    For example, there is feedback that many Singaporeans feel that instead of pledging the $5 billion to Indonesia as trade financing assistance, the Government should redirect this sum towards helping Singaporean companies that are going under. This is perhaps a good example of how difficult it is to strike a balance between competing demands. Ultimately, what is the swinging factor has to be the longer term value of each competing course of action, for we have limited resources. Seeking the Government's assistance to avert bankruptcy or a shake-out may seem to be a perfectly reasonable request. Deciding which companies or individuals to help, and help constructively, is however extremely difficult. It is inevitable that some may drop out of the economy in the course of this downturn, and this is something which is of course hard to accept.

Column: 817



    Sir, this economic crisis is both a test of political leadership and the robustness of Singaporeans. It calls for mutual trust and assurance that all parties, the Government, the economic sector and the population at large, will respond in a responsible manner. Whilst the Government should continue to show empathy, Singaporeans should be prepared to endure.

    There is no doubt in my mind that only when Singaporeans rally behind the Government and make the necessary adjustments, can we all cope with this crisis, emerge more cohesive, better prepared to tackle new challenges and realise further growth potential.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the rallying point for a country in times of crisis must be the political leadership. The Government must lead and must be seen to be leading in the process of alleviating the hardship and in the process of restructuring. In the midst of pessimism, the Government needs to encourage. Where people are disheartened, the Government needs to inspire. Where people are suffering, the Government should show that it cares.

    I agree with the motion that the Government can act in three ways. It can take short-term measures, it can take long-term measures, and it can rally the people. First, the short-term measures. I think the Government faces a genuine dilemma. Nobody, not even our competent Government, can tell how long and how severe the downturn will be. It depends on a whole host of external factors, Japan, China, US, Indonesia, and so on. And on top of that, the relatively painless measures that the Government can take are limited in effectiveness and in scope. For example, the traditional pump priming measures, such as increases in public sector spending and even temporary cuts in income tax and GST have limited effect because the Singapore economy is so externally driven. In 1986, for example, there was a 25% income tax rebate. This time around, because 70% of the people do not pay income tax, the effectiveness of an income tax rebate is therefore limited.

Column: 818



    What about policies to cut business cost? The problem is that every levy or charge has its specific micro allocation objective and reducing these charges would disrupt the attainment of these allocated goals. This applies, for example, to the foreign worker levy which is used to discourage use of unskilled foreign workers, ERP charges which discourage use of certain roads and utility charges. Even lowering the corporate income tax would be useful only for those companies which pay tax and is irrelevant for those suffering losses or those with pioneer status.

    Difficult though this message of limited effectiveness is, I think that it is important for all sectors, including the business community, to understand and to accept this. It is important for the business community to expect neither bailouts nor handouts. In my view, the $2 billion off-Budget measures announced in June are appropriate and sufficient for the time being. However, as the downturn gets worse in the future, a further round of off-Budget measures would be needed. The timing of the second round is all important. It should be early enough and large enough to have an impact. The action should be decisive and strong.

    I believe that the second round of measures should include some of the policy options mentioned above. They may not be as effective as we would like. However, in times of crisis, it is not just the hard and fast numbers which count. Confidence is all important and signals an impact that can extend beyond their actual dollar value.

    But we may have to face the harsh and painful reality that what would have the most direct impact on business costs is the reduction of labour costs. The variable component of wages which constituted 16% of total annual wages last year should be the first to go. Furthermore, in my view, the public sector should carefully consider what annual variable component it is going to give in December, if any, and announce this early in order to send a signal to other employers. And then, there is the CPF. Considering that more than

Column: 819

100,000 households are already withdrawing the maximum allowable from the CPF for housing loan payment, a CPF cut should only be used as a last resort and, even then, should be accompanied by means to help those with loan repayment difficulties. And this is where, I believe, a compassionate Government should chip in - the realisation that a CPF cut, or whatever cut, is needed in order to reduce labour costs would be painful, would be harsh and would affect many.

    Second, the long-term measures. As Lim Swee Say has spoken at length and very eloquently on these measures and I think he has given us a very good lecture on the economic possibilities, I shall not elaborate on these measures. Suffice to say that the Government can focus its mind and channel resources on the opportunities and that we do not need to wait for full recovery and once the region bottoms out, there are going to be growth areas. We also need to diversify and we should prepare ourselves for these opportunities and be quick on the uptake.

    The third role of the Government is to rally the people. A national crisis calls for all hands to be on deck. Everyone has a role to play. Allow me to outline what I think should be the role of business, workers and the community. First, the role of business. I have consulted a number of business leaders. Mr Stephen Lee, President of the Singapore National Employers' Federation (SNEF) has said that he supports the motion. He said that SNEF's stand is to minimise job losses. In order to stay afloat, companies can agree to stop hiring, they can agree to terminate contract work, cut overtime, cut the variable component of wages and redeploy staff. Retrenchment is the last resort. But it is a legitimate response to save the company.

    Second, the role of workers. Workers must be willing to be trained and flexible enough to ensure that there is no mismatch in capabilities. NTUC's effort in promoting retraining through the SRP and the Government's support for this effort has been crucial and timely. It is also

Column: 820

encouraging to note from Minister Lee Boon Yang's response this afternoon that workers nowadays are more willing to be retrained. Also, if workers are retrenched, they should not be choosy about job options.

    Third, financial institutions also have a role to play. It is understandable that they are concerned about non-performing loans. However, banks and financial companies should not take advantage of this situation to force companies and individuals to top up so long as they are able to service their loans. Also, while there is a lot going for the DBS/POSB merger, it does have a negative side effect on Credit POSB home loan repayments. It has been said that, at current levels, readjustment of Credit POSB interest rates to the DBS' level would, for a 20-year loan, require an increase in monthly repayment of $92 for every $100,000 borrowed. In other words, a person who borrowed half a million dollars on a 20-year loan would have his repayment increased by $460 a month, and not a small sum indeed. Considering that Credit POSB housing loans amount to an estimated $7-$8 billion, the effect of this on the economy is not small. Even though there is a grace period up to the end of 1999, and the adjustment will take place over a three-year period, this is definitely bad news for the mortgagees affected. Could not the grace period be extended at least by one year up to the end of the year 2000 to soften the blow on those who have already borrowed money from Credit POSB?

    Fourth, the community also has a role to play. During times of economic downturn, there are those in our society who are genuinely hit hard, families whose main breadwinners have been retrenched, wage cuts which eat into their already meagre income and so on. We do not have a social safety net in the form of unemployment benefits in Singapore. But what can be done at a time like this? It is for the community to bear in mind that there are those who are worse off than ourselves, and to continue to give. The Government should also increase funding

Column: 821

for the Government and voluntary welfare organisations precisely so that they can continue to help those in need.

    In conclusion, where there is confidence that the political leadership can implement the appropriate policies, convince the people to swallow the bitter medicine and unite society, half the battle is already won. I would like to state that I, for one, have that confidence in our Government and I am sure that this view is shared by many. This is the time to close ranks, face the crisis together as a nation.

    I support the motion.

perceived as not doing enough and leaving the job of upgrading to the NTUC. This is certainly a common perception.
